importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the latest update on the resumption of China-India flights, signaling a significant diplomatic development in bilateral relations.
The announcement of flight resumption occurs on a date following key diplomatic events, including Prime Minister Modi's visit to China, reinforcing the timing of the diplomatic thaw.
Flights were suspended during the pandemic, and the five-year freeze began in 2020, marking the start of a prolonged period of disrupted air and diplomatic ties.
The U.S. raised tariffs on Indian imports to 50% in September 2025, contributing to the geopolitical context that prompted China and India to strengthen ties as a countermeasure.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The five-year period from 2020 to 2025 represents the duration of the air travel freeze and broader diplomatic stand-off, which ended with the resumption of flights in 2025.

keyTakeAways: China Eastern Airlines will resume Shanghai-Delhi flights starting November 9, 2025, after a five-year suspension.
The flight resumption is part of a broader diplomatic thaw between China and India, triggered by rising U.S. trade tensions and pressure on both nations.
Flights will operate three times a week—on Wednesdays, Saturdays, and Sundays—on the Shanghai-Delhi route.
India's foreign ministry confirmed the return of commercial flights following Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s visit to China in the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation summit.
The resumption of flights follows a period of heightened conflict in 2020 when four Chinese and 20 Indian soldiers were killed in border clashes, leading to a military stand-off.
India's largest carrier, IndiGo, previously announced daily nonstop flights between Kolkata and Guangzhou, reflecting broader efforts to expand bilateral air links.
Guangzhou Baiyun International Airport supported the expansion of direct routes, including Guangzhou-Delhi, indicating a regional push for improved connectivity.

The diplomatic thaw is occurring amid U.S. belligerent trade policies, including a 50% tariff on Indian imports and a proposed 100% tariff on China and India, which may have incentivized China-India closer cooperation.

namedEntities.name: China Eastern Airlines
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: China Eastern Airlines is directly involved in resuming flights between Shanghai and Delhi, marking a key action in the diplomatic thaw between China and India.

namedEntities.name: India
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: India is a key partner in the diplomatic and commercial revival, with both government and private carriers like IndiGo taking active roles in restoring air links.

namedEntities.name: Delhi
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Delhi is a destination city for the resumed Shanghai-Delhi flights, symbolizing the reconnection of key urban centers between the two countries.

namedEntities.name: Shanghai
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Shanghai is the origin city for the resumed flights, representing a major economic and cultural hub in China, and a key point in China-India connectivity.

namedEntities.name: Narendra Modi
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Modi’s first visit to China in over seven years initiated discussions on trade and diplomatic relations, directly contributing to the resumption of flights.

namedEntities.name: United States
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: U.S. aggressive trade policies, including high tariffs on Indian and Chinese goods, have indirectly influenced China-India relations by creating economic incentives for closer bilateral ties.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former President of the United States
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump’s trade policies, particularly the proposed 100% tariffs on China and India, are cited as a catalyst for China and India to strengthen their own economic and diplomatic links.

namedEntities.name: Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The SCO summit where Modi met Chinese leaders provided a diplomatic framework for the discussion of improved trade and mutual cooperation.

namedEntities.name: IndiGo
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: IndiGo announced daily flights between Kolkata and Guangzhou, showing India’s private sector initiative to expand air connectivity with China.

namedEntities.name: Guangzhou Baiyun International Airport
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major international airport in China
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The airport supported the expansion of direct routes, signaling institutional support for China-India air travel revival.

namedEntities.name: Himalayan border
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A geographical region between India and China
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The border clashes in this region in 2020 led to a military stand-off and suspended flights, highlighting the conflict that preceded the current thaw.

summaryOfNewsArticle: China Eastern Airlines is resuming direct flights between Shanghai and Delhi, starting November 9, 2025, after a five-year suspension. This marks a significant diplomatic thaw between China and India, prompted by rising U.S. trade tensions and the aggressive tariff policies of former U.S. President Donald Trump. The flight schedule includes three weekly services on Wednesdays, Saturdays, and Sundays. The resumption follows deadly border clashes in 2020, which led to a prolonged military stand-off and halted air travel. India’s government and private carriers, including IndiGo, have also taken steps to expand air links, with support from Chinese airports such as Guangzhou Baiyun International Airport. This development reflects broader efforts to strengthen economic and diplomatic ties amid global trade volatility and U.S. pressure on both nations.
title: China Eastern Airlines to resume flights to India after five-year freeze
